2HaJE1tkwvPskIRjCn0-OQ.text: They filmed Tom Cruise enjoying a pint outside of this pub for Mission Impossible. The pub itself is ok, a bit touristy in the summer but it is quite nice sitting out by the river with a pint.

pDenZmy4zNQmJW2x8qJZ_w.text: This is a typical british pub, with its typical booze, food and decoration. It's placed next to the Thames, in the south shore. It was supposed to be a place frequented by famous writers, and it's easy to figure out why, with different rooms on the ground floor, a restaurant upstairs, and also two terraces: one on the first floor with fabulous views and other outside the building, being the closest you can get to the river. Unfortunately, there's no beer garden, but you won't miss it that much with all the riverside available for you. The prices are not expensive, but sometimes it can get quite overcrowded, meaning that ordering can be quite a nightmare, specially if you are hungry. Anyway, food is quite tasteful, despite they don't have anymore Sunday roast, one of their best. Instead, they have a wider selection of fish & chips, and you still can order your roast on the restaurant area.

xR05PzFJLct26WccEuyYZg.text: This is a great bar on the South Bank! Walk along from London Bridge along the cobbled lanes and its roight on the river. It has an outdoor area right by the river - great for summer!Its huge inside and has all these seperate alcoves and rooms - perfect if you have a group of people wanting their own area for a session.It has a nice atmosphere and a good crowd frequent it.They look like they are havigna big party there for the 26th of Jan - Australia day - so a place to be if you are aussie on that day - thats if you can pull yourself away from Shepards bush Walkabout.

0nPJh2G_bMhfbjhvrzYsbQ.text: There are some people who would say that al fresco, riverside drinking in November is just plain stupid. My intellectual retort to this arguement is: PAH! If you have a hood on your coat, a pair of pink striped mittens, a full bottle of wine and a packet of cigarettes, there is nothing the British weather can throw at you for which you are not prepared. And, by this rationale, so began an evening of drinking in the Anchor Bankside. Or, rather, outside it. I have to admit, I don't think I've ever actually drunk inside this pub. The outside patio area on the Thames is so alluring that we always, but always, sit outside: in the summer, when it's bursting with drinkers and you'll be hard pressed to find a table, and on nights like tonight, when we were the only crazy people choosing to be buffeted by the wind and rain under the billowing and creaking awnings The Anchor is the perfect spot for a bit of people-watching and putting the world to rights.

YzEIHY_yreTgw_VUZIiqew.text: The Anchor is firmly cemented on the tourist trail as far as pubs go in the area. The venue is large and airy inside and holds onto some historic charm from decades ago (well I imagine it does as I'm too young to know). It does get very crowded and noisy though and that means difficulty in getting served. A nice location along Bankside and a hop skip to Borough Market but there's many better drinking establishments in the area. Beers are boring and bland and once again better pubs close-by. The food looked traditional pub fare but I didn't order.

ebtyi4MXT_ROlyVEN40Clw.text: This pub is a split one  I have been here during the working week and got good fast service (food and drink), also here over the weekend and it's a different story, but can't them the staff as the numbers of people that get packed into this pub is unbelievable. Still nice place to get a drink and to sit outside. They could sort out teir toilets, it's never good mid-week or weekend

I-GrVEOuaiOD4TmcFkxUCQ.text: I like the anchor for its location, just as the other reviews say. It really is such a delightful feeling, having a pint with friends on an August afternoon, especially if you luck out and its actually sunny! A good place to relax after rummaging through Borough Market. Admittedly the service can be a bit shoddy, and the toilets could be cleaner, but really, what pub couldnt do with cleaner toilets?

nCDBsN-hz9McHxQ8S8-D-A.text: NEVER go to this pub! It happened three times people in my group had things stolen from them. Twice bags and last night, my cousin's wallet and mobile vanished from his pocket. I called the manager and he blamed us for not being careful enough. We were almost sitting on our bags! What is the point of going for a pint, not being able to relax, having something stolen and being blamed for it? I had to allocate a star to the review but I wouldn't recommend the place to anyone. A terrible place and terrible management.

eZovK_3sm6JIMQqMzesKAg.text: I work nearby and occasionally pop in after work. For me it is a run of the mill pub with slightly above average London prices. I personally wouldn't eat here but for an after work drink it suits me fine with the added bonus of a great outdoor area next to the Thames.

rEAZ9_k9nigvp7M6yen-Mw.text: pretty standard pub, no soul to the interior, but recommend on a nice summers day for the excellent location by the tamesdrinks aren't cheap, but its to be expected in such a touristy area of London town.

ZlkupyqXgMsuxLWkV41S7Q.text: This pub is a complete tourist trap and you can queue for ages to get a drink, especially on a summers day when you can grab a seat by the river and enjoy your drink. The food is reasonable and not too expensive considering the location, but unfortunately you do have to be careful with your belongings, I misjudged where my handbag was once and had it stolen.

ceUSkiQOUPMyjryCGmqtDA.text: No complaints on my visit to The Anchor.  The pub is pretty large, but we opted to go outside and sit by the river.  I had a vodka + club soda, which was fine.  Good tourist spot, but I don't think I would stay here for a lengthy amount of time.

ALRBvJPmy7K1M6U7YDwkIA.text: The Anchor is a traditional pub on the river. It is lacking in character and atmosphere and, as with lots of old pubs, the inside is fairly dingy and uninspiring. There is also an outside seating area with views across the river, which is very much the place to be.The clientele is a mix of business people, tourists and people walking up the river to visit the various museums etc. Consequently there isn't really much of a crowd to help make it feel less anonymous. The Anchor is a fairly inoffensive and bland pub. Fine for a drink outside if the weather's nice. Otherwise perhaps avoid.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

ZedAsKcKwN1s5Yczux3EhQ.text: large pub, lots of casual fun, even out door patios available.

I5-Jr64moQoWAzhWt2hDOw.text: The Mrs. and I enjoyed a Sunday roast at the Anchor Bankside when we ran across it after a tour of the Globe Theatre, fortunately at 1130 before the lunch rush. The Anchor is in a tourist location, but it is also the oldest pub in London. The location is right on the Thames so eating on the deck could be fun, but we went in the bar.The staff was very friendly and helpful. They gave me sample tastes of the ales so I could make my selections (thanks Anchor!) and helped me figure out that you order and pay at the bar. The food selection in the bar was fairly extensive (but the sticky toffee pudding is only available in the (more expensive) restaurant section). We found the entire place to be clean, including the loos (restrooms).I enjoyed two different ales and we both had the Sunday (beef) roast. While the roast was decent, it was obvious that it was mass produced and did not have an in-house cooked flavor.We would stop there again if we were in the area. For the excellent staff, cleanliness, ale selection and value, 4 stars.

keM2R1SZs58nJlZzNdwCKw.text: I understand why this place isn't reviewed well - it's wholly unremarkable inside. I wouldn't go if I had to be inside. But the large seating area outside makes it good. And here's why:You can find a sunny spot next to the Thames with a great view of St Paul's Cathedral on the north side of the river. The cobblestone street will inevitably result in some good people watching as well - a favourite pastime of mine. Clearly it's a tourist spot since it's in close proximity to Borough Market and the Globe, but did I mention you can find a sunny spot on the Thames?I noticed the pub in the background during a Get Him to the Greek scene. If it's good enough for Aldous Snow, it's good enough for me.

lkeknNdFzhcyV7NVeZ7oeg.text: I went to Anchor Bankside after work with my girlfriend for a meal. The menu at Anchor Bankside was small but the service was good and the table staff didn't bother us every five minutes to make sure that the food was ok.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

Ou9R2O4_EydUyi5ixj6XZQ.text: Busy South Bank of Thames pub with good beer and fast service. Always busy and can get cramped inside, with tides of people as the nearby offices close in the evenings. There's a large amount of external seating (also busy) and so there will usually be people standing alongside the river, with its good views across to St Pauls. Pub grub and more seating upstairs, which still requires getting there early to be sure of a seat. Some reviewers say the service is slow; its one of those places that just has huge demands from the staff and the ones that can really work the bar can shift orders fast. Its also good to catch an eye and some staff can be stacking the orders well. Otherwise it could be a long wait. Experienced ordering required ;-) Oh yes, its old - circa 16-something.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Anchor - on the Thames

u-w9bUqJ391wZNM8Q39EuQ.text: I love this place.It is nice little walking distance from Borough Market.It has a huge beer Garden in front of the Thames.Also in the summer has a BBQ going with amazing sausages and burgers.Worth a trip

YZ4E-DhzC5sOHpkDGmbTRw.text: If your a tourist pop in for a pint to say you've been here. Everyone else steer clear. This pub promises so much, outside seating, right on the river, fish and chip shop inside, summer BBQ and its a traditional English pub (former brothel I think from 16th century!) but it just doesn't deliver. Most staff don't speak English and those that do are miserable to the point where I want to shake them. The food is average and every single time I have eaten here both me and my friend have had quesy stomachs the next day. The drink prices are tourist prices so expect to overpay. The toilets are gross and often flooded. In the summer its packed due to its location - you can see its attractions but I wonder how may people go back?. The only reason i've been here more than once is that I used to work next door so it was often used as an 'office do' venue. Avoid this pub if possible - instead go for one of the many off the beaten track English pubs the other side of Borough High Street.

JK2k0IVmOt7Rnjd_NfccAg.text: The Anchor is, without a doubt, the worst pub in London. Don't bother trying to reserve a table because when you arrive, your area will be occupied, filthy and possibly without chairs. The food is terrible and they don't make it easy to order either. Last night, they were randomly closing bars and directing patrons to other bars to order food. After being redirected twice, we gave up and were going to share with our friends but ultimately decided to leave the cold fish and cardboard chips to them to enjoy. The food isn't brought to your table either, you're given a pager and have to go fetch it. It is no surprise then that patrons decide to fetch food from the neighbouring take away places instead. Most importantly, the toilets are diabolical. Filthy, no toilet paper and the lights were off in the passage way. What a horrible pub.

IJLWjiFc4FLPQ3RqXXm-zw.text: A massive pub but its for tourists only as the service is terrible. Fair enough it gets busy but look how well the Market Porter just round the corner deals with being busy, the staff here just don't really care.

aQ12TIGIqMy76fcwq_19uA.text: The Anchor Bankside is appealing because it is an old pub but beneath the elderly exterior, it is really just an average riverside pub.The views are lovely - especially in the summer but that is probably just about the only element that makes this pub special. It can get busy at times, especially at lunch but this ends to be from the surrounding companies and tourists. It doesn't have much of a friendly local pub vibe, and even on a night there isn't any atmosphere.The food is ok - I have tasted better. The chips are very nice though - big and chunky but that is probably the best choice to go for in my experience! The food is also very expensive and the portions rather small. My friend actually ordered 2 for himself!

uzCD32R8WHjMZX39TnEpJw.text: An utterly unremarkable pub.  The beer on offer is limited, they're usually really busy and under staffed so expect a frustrating wait at the bar whilst they serve people in the wrong order.Considering the pub itself has been around since the 1600's (or something) the interior is awful and unauthentic.  It has a Wetherspoons feel.On the up side, the Chips I had from the Fish and Chip shop above the pub were pretty good and it has a really large seating area outside by the River - but it does get very busy!

BwtIS4txdAGFFCfppd3Ywg.text: This place is a labyrinth, all sorts of stairs and doors and sections. Actually arrived in a decent sized group but we Brownian motioned ourselves into a few different groups in different parts of the bar (the upstairs outside area is to be recommended!). This pub is ancient too, it was rebuilt in 1676 (after a fire I guess, but not the great fire), so who knows when it was first built. 17th century perv and author Samuel Pepys (come on  everyone came across him at school at some point!) supposedly watched the Great Fire of London from this vantage point. Apparently the number of tourists here can get a bit annoying but I didn't particularly notice. Whatever - they serve some good ales at their many bars and I expect to be trying to get a table on the roof terrace some time this summer.

U2d7Ieb-JKCDK1QYAEQuAA.text: Your regular pub - without much character though and the homey everyone-knows-everyone feel - as it is right beside the Thames and therefore can be a tourist spot. Service is lacking as well. The space is huge though - with a lot of choices to offer: tea, food, drink outside, etc.The view of the River from their rooftop is amazing, I was reading here during the summertime for hours.

IfTHFvU2eqjMNQHv7hTorQ.text: Love the fish and chips here- best I've had in all of the UK, Ireland, and Oz. Will have to make sure to stop by the next time I go to London.

ff9R-yaUmUEn_uFl1dn_Vw.text: Looks can be deceiving.Anchor is a huge pub located on the south bank of the thames close to Southwark Bridge. I have walked past on a number of occasions and have always wanted to go in ... attracted by its open riverside seating area and the roof terrace. I went there twice recently during the world cup. On the first trip we had booked a table upstairs but during the second i had just walked in.First shock. Just 4 tv screens in the whole pub which probably had more than 10 different seating areas. Two downstairs and two upstairs and only one in the open air. There were multiple rooms without tv's ... which is not cool if you are advertising that all 64 matches would be shown there.Second. The service. I understand that pubs in England are notoriously slow but this one was an order of magnitude slower than the rest. People had started queuing up at the bar from long before the match was about to start. I reached the counter after kick-off. The fact that the game had started did not affect the bartender's service standard at all. He poured the whisky and then stopped to do some work with the wine list with his colleague while i waited. After i paid by card, my receipt had been printed but he was too busy chatting to notice ... and all this while the match was going on. I got extremely irritated.Third. During half time one of us went to the bar to order some food. They said that food wasn't available, neglecting to mention that we could order in a different room. We were quite surprised to see later that people were eating. Well ... it was Anchor which lost some business.Fourth. When i went for the second time, to watch the 3rd-4th place play-off between Germany and Uruguay, i found that it was being shown on only one of the 4 screens ... the others were, believe me or not, switched off.The only reasons i am giving them 2 stars and not one are that they serve Black Label and their fish and chips is not significantly below average.

pwAxw2DGxB6RgQ4nWJU11Q.text: This is quite a grubby pub but in a great location right on the river. Uber busy in the summer, the pubs interior is not particularly nice and I think most of their trade comes from tourists.Not really a locals pub but nice to sit outside in the summer.

HlP9jUoJhtl4V9n0Gr7HyQ.text: The Anchor is an institution in London; not only is it the site of an original pub dating back before the Great Fire of London, but this particular pub has been there since 1676!The best thing about the Anchor is, of course, its location. There is abundant outdoor seating right on the river's edge. If you can't get a seat there, or would rather eat, there is plenty of room inside, over two levels, and diners can sit outdoors on the second level and look out over the Thames.Admittedly, the food is basic, and I've actually seen them heating up a microwave-meal lasagne, but hey, it's simple pub fare, and nothing beats sitting on the river's edge with a cool pint in the summer.

ilT0LUVpakwwlJeh9z-Frg.text: The 1 star goes to the fact that they have indeed beer! Stay away from this place. Horrible fish and chips (barely reminds you fish or chips), redicoulusly overpriced, confirms the statement of staying away from touristic shops. If you want the view of the river better buy a beer fron any place and have it outdoors.

PJtrv4QycZ5EAZjkmTWAkA.text: We came here for a visit to escape the biting wind of the Thames and to sit down after transporting a couple of heavy bags around through Tower Bridge and the South Bank after checking out of the hotel. It's very much a "tourist trap" although some of the patrons appeared to be City workers unwinding after a day in the office. The gentleman who took my order from me was very pleasant although I would say that prices were above what I would call standard pub fare. However, I detract. The chips and side of bread & butter were delicious and warming!I have deducted one star for the state of the toilets. They weren't dirty but definitely lacked any attention in the decoration stakes. I would say that the dull paintwork and lighting gave it the aura of dirtiness. Would I recommend here? Based on my first visit, I would. There's a decent seating area outside which would be ideal for the Summer months.The staff were friendly and polite and after the hustle and bustle of being pushed around by the man on the street it made a pleasant change!

0yYJq2yCCkwMC2SvwEtC2g.text: I went here for lunch with my sister and dad, and it was a great spot for classic pub food. We had the steak and ale pie, fish and chips, and veggie burger, and all were amazing! It was a Saturday afternoon so it was busy and hard to find a table, and crowded to order drinks and food at the bar, but we weren't in a rush and really enjoyed the meal. It is a neat pub with lots of small rooms, and they also have a patio for the nice weather. This pub would be family friendly for those with children.

8fGxUPLwgxEBEQzP982fiw.text: A complete tourist trap with horrible food and mediocre beer. My fish and chips the fish was tasteless and tough.

F2e9G_6rEtMRgGgad7rS_Q.text: I can't tell you anything about the food, but it had a great atmosphere and great drinks. We sat on the big river side patio that overlooks the Thames. Great place to stop for a drink and enjoy the scenery. The building was also quite nice and large.

Vjxy6A1Z-3Pcv-hS4VhhbQ.text: While it was cool to eat at such an old and well known English pub, the service and food wasn't anything to get excited about. We ate out on the patio and it took forever to get our order in. My husband and I both thought the food was okay. Wish it had been a better experience!

25-s9kICO9IYrd_vM6gfWQ.text: This pub shares the name of a dive bar relatively close to my heart.  It was less inspiring of affection, but I did have a good time at this Anchor.During my time in London I happened on a few pubs that shared an identical menu, down to the font and drawing of fish on the cover.  This was one of them.  If someone could explain this chain of unapparent chain pubs, I would appreciate it.I didn't eat here, but I did indulge in a couple bottles of some reasonably priced, potable wine with a few friends.  The place was big, with a nice relaxed atmosphere suggestive of a long and very British history.  Service at the bar was efficient and friendly enough.  Otherwise, I have very little to report.  I had a good time, but I don't exactly have strong feelings about this Anchor.Also, of all the places to have a Wikipedia page: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An….

crr-CSw3b_bOoC9qI0274A.text: Raining and in search of a pub that was not packed on a Friday night, we came to The Anchor. Crap service as the bartender spilled the beer on two people in my group hitting the tap as he lifted it over the counter. No apology. Crap beer as it tasted .... bad. Relatively empty and a dirty bathroom. Find somewhere else.

y0sOlrwZRW6tFce9fvJFPg.text: Undoubtedly a bit of a tourist trap, but good food, enormous portion of fish in the fish and chips, could reasonably feed two people on the one dish. Nice selection of beers and cider on tap, and pretty well packed on a Friday night, so if you're after a quiet romantic dinner, probably not the right place. For a stereotypical British pub experience, though, it's definitely fun.

v19EQFesNzQcmlk066nhBg.text: Charming atmosphere, but it feels touristy. Good selection of beers on tap. We didn't eat so I can't comment on the food. It's a fine place to stop for a drink, but I think better options exist nearby.

smzGI6W0vS5GGYEHXNoebw.text: I remember this place of old before the Borough was fashionable and before they built the ghastly hotel on the back and the extension by the garden.  It was worth a visit then.  It isn't any more.Tolp tip:  If you are passing in the mrning and fancy a bacon sandwich walk-on-by they will tell you to have the hotel buffet breakfast which isn't expensive for what it is but £9 is outrageous for a sandwich.

P99yqV35BP3OHGVjJWhv5w.text: Awesome! The Anchor was built in the 1600's and stands today! It's along the Queen's walk, so it's a great place to stop in and have lunch or dinner. It also feels very old with large wooden beams and a lot of retrofitting. It's an experience. Touring London, it was a great place to grab a beer and a plate of bangers & mash.

azzXoJ1hGQdAKN_LdWx46A.text: OK beer.Bad food.Worse service.Pimms from a tap.Nice location if it's sunny. (but, then, it's on the south side of the river where all the nice stuff to look at is and where the shadows come first, so...)Not as expensive as they could have made it.Patience with staff, customers, neighbours, cyclists, and more required. But you'll end up here anyway, at some point. Expect bad, and it'll be nicer.(Apparently Samuel Pepys watched the Fire from here)

KnckHyy3tfzR9mdkyFPELg.text: Great old fashioned style pub with oodles of history.  Lots of rooms to have your own little meeting spot during the day while everyone else is at work.  The toilets however do need a make over as a little dingy and smelly, pew wee.  Great location  for quick drink whilst enjoying the South Bank.  Avoid early evening as it is manic with the workers but if your on the hunt for someone special then maybe it's the right place to be?! Xoxo

gxd8frAp2clnwd1y5Ypaqw.text: Do use this as a central meeting point for a group of you.Do take advantage of the beer garden out the front when it's warmDo keep an eye on your belongingsDon't eat here. Really, don't.Do enjoy the views of the river.Don't ask the staff for too much more than a drink, because they won't understand you.Don't stay here all night.Do come here expecting bad service, and maybe be pleasantly surprised.

OBcP0NUn-1Z_cbF5GADZ0w.text: Absolutely dreadful food. Just interested in serving cheap low quality food at extorniate prices. Avoid and pick up anything from the stall at Borough Market instead.

fuusqJID3b53qtcgrloDsw.text: On the bank of the Thames with a lot of outdoor seating. During my many trips to London, I find myself down here at least once near sunset to enjoy a pint on the river Thames. Good food but the view and Pints are better.

0lbVr5npgRCQFqhEgqankw.text: The Anchor Bankside is a wonderful historic building located right on the banks of the River Thames.  It has enjoyed a colourful history providing services to the local community since 1822.  Nowadays, however, the only services this place provides are aimed at increasing the already large numbers of tourists that come for the 'quaint' appeal of this drinking establishment.  As such continued refurbishments have robbed it of much of its original character and the prices and quality of service have respectively gone up and down.The Anchor is massive.  Set over a sprawling four floors it incorporates a fish and chip shop, restaurant, bar, roof terrace and a tearoom.  The large outdoor spaces of this pub make it an extremely popular location during the summer months.The atmosphere here is loud and raucous and the crowd made up predominantly of office workers, tourists and a few shoppers from the nearby Borough Market.  After office hours the place can become filled to the rafters so this place is one to avoid if you're after a quiet drink.In terms of drinks you'll find a decent selection of bottled and draught beers but not much else besides.  The tourist trade ensures that the prices here can also be quite steep.It's a shame that such a rich historic building as this has been rinsed of the identity it once had, hopefully other historic pubs will not go the same way.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

opboWZ1ZWC4FoubzWGj8Og.text: Bought a nicely overpriced drink here. Sat outside in the light drizzle which was still enjoyable. Inside gets packed. Bathrooms are not great. But it did the job.

FgohpBiW0Om9E3tJNN6Wcw.text: Massive tourist trap of a pub along the Thames that's rumored to have been a watering hole for Shakespeare and other olde famous English people as well as a brothel and various other interesting establishments. The place is worth going into if you're walking along the riverbank for a quick pint or some fish n' chips, but it's not the best pub by a long shot. There are a ton of rooms, a bunch of bars, and plenty of places to sit, which make it a bit fun to wander around in and explore. Service is pretty atrocious, but I don't expect much at a pub anyways. Worth popping in to check out and come to your own conclusions.

fojZHN_K_ICPODGT0QheSw.text: First off, I'm visting from the US, so I'm no expert, but in the few days I've been here, this is the worst pub we've been to.I'll never go back, there are too many other choices. The fish and chips were bad and not even hot. The sausage roll was basically a large hotdog in the same (crappy) batter as the fish and chips. The service was "meh". We got served, but nobody smiled or made us feel like we were welcome there.We went in the first place because the location and building look amazing. So they go that going for them, which is nice.

TfrSPT0XHYnep4PZd1iyOQ.text: I love the Anchor because it epitomizes summer in London. The pub is always full of hustle and bustle, people from all walks of life are sitting in the sun on the roof, drinking a pint, eating some English pub delightful food and reveling in the beautiful weather. The view of the Thames and the surrounding area is outstanding, and I always feel like a local when coming here...

kK3pBJiiu386PcIjCQWJAA.text: Hopelessly touristy but the offerings are steadily consistent. You can't beat the location -- sublimely planted on the south bank of the Thames, near the Shakespeare Globe, The Anchor's facade embodies everything about charming London pubs: beautifully potted outdoor flowers, stone scaffolds, chalkboard signs, cask ales and MEAT PIES. The steak and ale pie was surely frozen and then heated - -but it didn't stop it from being pretty G-damn delicious. This isn't a bad stop on a warm (or cold!) day during a stroll. It's just not particularly remarkable. There isn't a neighborhood feel and it's chock a block with tourists. Still, when you need a drink, you need a drink.

4_v7qGDmMtwk1PZx6eAjRw.text: Great cocktails with a true pub atmosphere along the Thames River.  If you want to drink at one of the oldest most ornate pubs in London this is your place.   We did not eat here.

4jETV-7O7Z5yHotaPX6Gww.text: Originally a classic and famous pub. It burned down a couple years ago and they did a nice job restoring the facade (except for the ghastly illuminated plastic sign in place of the previous brass one) but the interior has lost its previous charm. Four or five cask ales and many more taps of stuff that shouldn't be poured in a real pub, but it's very busy and I suppose that most of the tourists (unlike me) want the same stuff they can get in the States or in Europe. They've expanded and updated the terrace. It now has it's own bar and wicker chairs instead of the previous picnic benches.  Directly upon the river, it's a very pleasant spot when the weather is nice.

KoNbAx31HErDijv33ciBpg.text: I will start by saying I am a shameless tourist. As most people have stated, this is a tourist trap, but we enjoyed it. We walked past it at a point in our day when we were hungry for anything and it wasn't crowded at all, around 1pm on a Monday. Ordered at the bar and the food was delivered to the table. It was hot and tasted ok. Good serving size filled me up. Bathrooms weren't as dreadful as has been stated.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Some fish and chips. It was ok.

lC9p0ocScsHnJq9rfuZXWA.text: It's hard to rate any old English pub poorly, considering the history and heritage each one possesses. We finished our night time on the river Thames bike tour with a pint from the anchor pub. According to our tour guide its one of the oldest in the cities. What I found to make this pub stand out from the others is that it was playing "club" top 40 music....some may love that, some may not.

gqzqLKv-0uF5NHt_oPogpg.text: Went in here before we saw our show at the Globe and had a Sunday roast while watching Wimbledon on the TV. The staff was a bit rude, especially when compared to the others at comparable locations...but seeing how this is in the "tourist" area, I'm assuming they get real tired real fast.The food was delicious. Chicken, veggies, gravy, and whatnot washed down with a lovely cider. The restrooms are annoyingly all the way down on the first floor.

off6R5wHpIHN0rQMVgjnDw.text: I have fond memories of my recent visit to the Anchor.  I was able to enjoy a few pints along the river in their beer garden and even got a sunburn.  The location is great and makes it a tourist trap.  I've never eaten here, just drank some good beers of which they have a nice variety.  Since the usual gloomy weather parted and the sun baked London, everyone was outside and the riverwalk was a popular place to be.  The beer garden was splendid on this particular day and I found myself a quiet table and read my book, people watched and had a few nice brews.  Whenever I'm around Borough Market, The Globe or Tate Modern I always make my way here for a pint.  Sunburned, in London.  I can't make this stuff up.

38hXpuwLMp0sN6OMjEqN0A.text: Torn again on reviewing an English pub. The building has so much charm, it's old, beautiful, and cozy. They also have outdoor seating. BUT, once again, they have been commercialized and have the same menu of every pub I visited in London. It's basically a chain restaurant, in a really nice building. The rumor is that Shakespeare used to drink here, so it would be nice if they had an old school traditional menu. But, it is a fun little bar, with an outdoor deck and patio. We had an appetized and the Pimm's pitcher and we enjoyed our time. If they could fix the menu, I would definitely be back again!

k_ENK8LB7iC2qV5QXAtDzg.text: On the London river cruise they said the anchor was the oldest bar in London and thought we'd check it out. Had their famous fish and chips and while the portion size was quite large it was average. Sat on the outside patio and atmosphere and drinks were good so that made up for the average food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Cod and chips

Ix65h24hFmjHCfBW1OiT1A.text: If you have heard about bad British pub food, this place will male your dreams come true. The service is slow and they could not process credit cards. The fish and chips was dry and oily, leaving a bad taste in the mouth after eating. I couldn't eat my dinner and was put off food for 3 days after dining here. You have been warned!

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Eat at your own risk

Y08SAN0aHBkAQ95MtYI5RQ.text: Again. located on the Southbank between Blackfriars Bridge and London Bridge. The Anchor features a traditional interior, with a low ceiling, exposed brickwork and wood panelling. It has a cosy ambience. Again, this pub is at it's most popular in the summer due to the fact that it is located on the Thames overlooking St Pauls cathedral.

TpIMS4eHMjw86yWzswScvA.text: Nice little place. Were a little off with us about the food and where we could sit mind. Nice enough little pub though in good location when walking along embankment

Be5bqCsYFKTxD7phGq2q5Q.text: Decent place to grab a beer.  Some tables are a little oddly placed, but generally good atmosphere.  Could improve local beer selection.

kUfEQ1Krj2COYL376jdcJw.text: Pretty good pub considering what a tourist trap it could be sitting right there on the Southbank. An absolute labyrinth of a place, it's got room after room and floor after floor of space, bar and terrace (and even a slightly separated, covered and raised up terrace overlooking the water).I've ended up here simply to escape the rain (twice), as well as for pre-meditated Friday night work drinks and in the middle of the week day because I was just around and needed a break. The first time we stumbled in on an England v Australia rugby match, so the place was packed, loud and slightly terrifying. Though somehow we managed to get a table for four -- which is either a testament to how large this place is or (more likely) we sat directly under the TV which meant it was a table without a view that no one wanted :)More recently I came for work drinks, during which one of the upper floor rooms was reserved for our group. We had a small dedicated bar and bartender, while the space was tucked away and had access to an almost private upper-floor terrace. It worked well for our group of 40-50.I think most people will be tempted to hunker down and get lunch or dinner here, but I don't recommend it. It's a lovely place to rest your feet with a pint, warm up by the fire and dry off if you've been doing the tourist thing all day, but there is better food to be had very close (try Nando's for chicken, GBK for burgers, PizzaExpress for pizza/salads or, if it's a Thurs-Sat during the day, walk around the corner to Borough Market for a plethora of unique food stalls).

KFCnYtT5ScKPjzDU2GtSTw.text: Given it's location, this is obviously a touristy pub. Still, it's got some good ambiance and a view that can't be beat if you're sitting outside on a warm afternoon.The food is entirely average. The burgers aren't bad, but they certainly won't impress your taste buds like a masterful creation from Byron. A weird caveat - when I ordered at the bar they told me it'd take 45 minutes for two burgers. This is around 6pm on a weekday. I said fine, but 15 minutes later our burgers arrived. So I'm not sure what that was about, but just FYI for anyone else who encounters the same!

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Storefront
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. A very fuzzy picture of a very busy bar!

NLIRE_Z0qeZxPID61NF1og.text: Fish and chips. Tap brews. Pub fare. What you see is what you get. They say Shakespeare used to drink around here somewhere between gigs.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

-sf6rn-gguvDBlKc34U3bA.text: I find myself here a lot, mostly because I go to the Shakespeare Globe a lot, and I just wish that this place was either slightly cheaper OR had better beer on tap.They have all the standard stuff - Stella, Heineken, Strongbow, yadda yadda - but you wind up paying almost £5 if not more for a pint! A G&T here cost about £5.50. Yikes.Nice location, great place to unwind after a long day (especially in the summer, when they open up the patio seating area) but in the end, it feels like what it was always intended to be: a tourist trap.

VzpVbPEieVE5ojpaGOMGZg.text: Nice interior, pretty authentic. Food was very average. We had the roast beef. Way too much gravy, too much salt and the Yorkshire pudding was like rubber. Their 1730 pale ale was decent.

KLLkA7WoJrdopDuM9MeNYQ.text: This pub was a bit overwhelming if I'm honest. A beautiful building on the outside and absolutely huge but inside it had become so commercialised and had lost all of its original old charm. There were loads of different sections to it and different bars and restaurant areas within it, which made the toilets quite a challenge to find. Although it was quite fun exploring it at the same time!There was a craft beer bar in a room off the main bars but unfortunately that was closed at the time. They also had a fish and chips bar on one of the levels which I thought was a great idea. I didn't eat there but the fish looked and smelled delicious!

Il0dQ9SZsB2hY94N7o_X7A.text: My first introduction to British fish and chips and mushy peas did not disappoint. The portion sizes were huge and the fish was lightly crusted and very tasty. Paired it with a cider, and had a great time in a fun pub environment.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Fish & Chips
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry and Lime cider

I7HgzavTNDYj9E8LhnE42w.text: Screwed up setup, blah food....  not impressed.  Don't waste your time or money.Will not be back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

qa80cNkiJ278ZqGlbmcElw.text: The most advertised menu item... fish and chips (of course). But, you can't serve fish & chips when you have NO CHIPS! Bar tender couldn't care less and had no idea how to make a martini. I know, it's a pub. But it's London and I even said "shaken, not stirred." Actually, I didn't. But in James Bond's own country, they should've been able to take care of me.

HCug_RDqv5Shut7jCypmRQ.text: Great pub! My wife and I were visiting from New York, and are admittedly not the curators of London cuisine, but we had some great food and a great time! Service was quick and friendly, the prices were definitely a bit steep compared to some of the other pubs we visited, but we felt the end justified the means. This place is a bit of a landmark, and you definitely pay for it, but the interior and exterior are adorable, and the location is bar-none right on the Thames. Notes for outsiders (like us!): There is traditionally no wait service at pubs in London (probably everywhere in the UK? I can only speak to London). You order and pay at the bar and the food is brought to your table. The ordering and paying also takes place at the same time. Additionally, tipping is a whole different ball game here. What most of the locals and others explained is that tip is not expected but is appreciated and you typically just round off your bill with the tip. For example, if you bill is 27.50 pounds, you can be nice and just give them 30 and call it even. Maybe we're wrong, but that's what everyone seemed to be doing.Now, a vast number of the pubs in London are "Fuller's" pubs. I never really understood this entirely, but it basically means that the menu and beers are extremely similar everywhere you go with slight deviations (a different pie here, a different beer there) but we were a little confused when so many of the pubs (despite having different names) were nigh carbon copies of each other as far as the menu went. We didn't complain, because it was all great and we were having great experiences, but that was definitely noteworthy.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. It's pie!
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. A+ for the choice of red. This place is as cool as it looks. We loved it!

MEIAx9aSPxJg8ubM0xyHSA.text: Good fish and chips, and chicken pie, however the beers listed were all missing. Service was lacking and the tables were dirty. This place is gorgeous on the outside but not a nice dinner place to come to.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

tkzt0JARWmpQ_NY-hXMENw.text: A British delight, Pimms!Other than the one my in-laws made, this was the best most refreshing cocktail we had!Perfectly mixed with a variety of fruits, bubbly and simply delish! Perfect for a warm summer day and enjoying their outdoor seating!

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom. Great cocktail

NtssuFS5WBo9XvvZZXlfyg.text: Yummy cider.. great food.. Cozy place, with great service. Upstairs n downstairs, so plenty of space. Fish n chips are finger licking good

Fd4ML3jlefnqVFGMoyA3LA.text: Major tourist trap!Was likely amazing before commercialization.Terrible food and service! Awful! Avoid!!!The only reason I gave it 2 stars is because the building it very cool.Maybe have a pint and then move on.

ZCi4Xk1ctKj13hIxfEbOjg.text: Apparently Shakespeare and Charles Dickens has had a drink here so I had to try it. Excellent location overlooking river Thames. Classic pub with a very classy interior. Big selection of beers. Famous for fish and chips. And oh for the vegetarians folks, they have veggie fish (cheese) and chips on the menu too. It was ok though. The balcony on the 1st floor has nice views. Check it out.

-jEwPVmRuVKEfrtLmDnY0g.text: Horrible service waited nearly 2hrs to get our food.  Prices are ok but I'm sure you can go to any other location and get the same thing. So don't waste you time here

gVWWiG2MUHiCSbzED8g8SA.text: Really loved this pub, especially with its ties to Shakespeare and old historic London! This is the kind of pub I remember going to with my mom when I was a kid traveling through Ireland and England. Dark, cozy with lots of happy laughter and drink clinking. We were just stopping by after a visit to the Globe, so we only had beers. Would like to come back next time for the full meal. You can't beat the atmosphere here. They also have a nice patio outside right on the river if it's a nice day. Have fun!

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

KvkIYH_lR0Vwzx_Jub4BHQ.text: Great food, in classic British pub setting by Thames. Have to get used to ordering at the bar. Ciabatta garlic bread and curried lentil soup was amazing. Vast selection of beers.

DWYBb5CRx0Xv7aTADAU6Qw.text: Beautiful looking from the outside, lot of character from the outside and brilliant location - as many before me have written.Lots of space inside, but maze like in the ground floor and a nice out door patio to sit. Went after dark so the view was so so.From the fare perspective - while the bar tenders were friendly they didn't have basic single malts we asked for, asked for a double gin and tonic but I believe I got vodka lemonade instead. I am was told by my friends that the house wine was nice.Food was below average - we ordered some veggie nachos but it was too salty. We asked for some ketchup for the chips which never came. No one cleared the tables on cue and there were broken chairs lying around which had the potential to cause serious bodily harm - with protruding nails.As many would agree - looks good from the outside, nice location that's pretty much it. Tourists might enjoy but  I will probably  not visit again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Anchor - London, United Kingdom

9bFYLbdrnZeM3i9fVvE4xA.text: Unlike our first visit, the weather has changed, so an inside seat was required. Always a busy pub but you can always find a table somewhere. Friendly people so sharing can be fun and you never know those other sharers may like a chat, especially if they are visitors and want a little help with the ways of London. Plenty of space and a good choice of beers. Quick service even though very busy.

2TCtywwR9lJwbdGl_cFaQQ.text: This was the worst restaurant we went to in our eight days in London! Very very slow service, nobody pays attention to the customers, food came out very cold after we asked several times when it was coming. Tasted terrible, nothing good about this experience except the fact that it is Bankside, on the Thames.  And close to the globe theater. Probably don't care to treat their customers well, when they'll get more anyway, based on location.

Ji6GdMnuBxjQgZkwh-U3VQ.text: Hungry on the South BankWe found ourselves on the South Bank during a day in London. In a very busy tourist deluged area, the dilemma was trying to find a lunch spot that would would satisfy our hunger and not be just awful. After a brief  look see, we decided to give this place a try.Of course we had to try the fish & chips as this was an obvious specialty. My order was served hot in a large portion to satisfy just about anyone.In a high volume tourist dominated spot, The Anchor was better than what we expected.

jGoSq5Ygx_PidoY05zeJqw.text: We really enjoyed our lunch here. Instead of using public transport, we walked everywhere in London, so we really worked up an appetite. I had the mushroom and beef pie, and it came with a side of vegetables that were actually al dente! It was delicious- one of the better pub meals we had. It's certainly in a convenient location.

nhKKycBN3356FVaQ-C3WWw.text: We are tourists and while the location is nice, the food was just so-so. We ordered the fish and chips and while the fish itself was nice, we ended-up picking off the batter because it was a bit soggy.  They had poor timing on our order - one came out quickly, the other came out when we were nearly finished. They were nice about taking it off our bill.

5_niLhYg2JLbAfEukujSlg.text: Stopped in for lunch on our first day...very charming exterior, a bit touristy inside (the pinball machines don't harken the 1800s so much ;o)However, we had a nice time here....food was tasty, especially the Big Ben Burger. Several nice cider selections for me...aka the drinking lightweight.

_rWGgCWBisSi_P_PYMLHcw.text: Poorly skilled bartenders. I went here for food with some friends who were visiting from Canada. The bar wasn't busy, but the two female bar staff couldn't cope. They were taking absolutely no notice of which customers arrived at the bar first and they allowed at least two people to jump the queue. When my friends went to the bar, they said the exact same thing happened to them. Part of being a decent bartender is noticing who has been waiting the longest. It seems like these bartenders aren't skilled or trained for their jobs. I dread to think what it's like when the bar is actually busy. I'd never go back here. I prefer to be served by professional bar staff. I was embarrassed to have taken my friends to this place.
